title: How to Use a Reflector in Travel Portraiture

steps.headline: Get your reflectors.
steps.description: The best kind to get are the ones that will fold up very small with multiple colors of reflectors. There are several brands. Get what works best for you. You can bring larger ones that fold up in the same way for more elaborate shots, but you won't be carrying all of that gear while being a tourist!

steps.headline: Keep it with you in your camera bag at all times.

methods.name: Use It as a Light Source

steps.headline: If you are in a darkened room or house and don't want to use your flash, position your subject appropriately.
steps.description: You want him facing a direction that you will be able to utilize existing light.

steps.headline: Position the reflector under the chin, about chest height or so, and make sure the reflector is reflecting any available light.
Open your lens as far as it will go.
steps.description: You want as much light to get in as possible.

steps.headline: Make sure that your shutter speed is set high enough that you won't have to worry about camera shake, unless you are using a tripod.
steps.description: You will probably have to experiment with the different speeds. Too fast, the scene will be dark, too slow, your subject will move or blink, or any of a hundred different things.

steps.headline: Set your ISO as low as you can get it.
steps.description: You probably don't want grain, so you don't want it high. Start out at about 200 and go from there.

methods.name: Filling a Face and Preserving a Background

steps.headline: Put your subject where you need them to be.
Expose for the background.
steps.description: If you try to expose for the subject, then the background will be very blown out.

steps.headline: Have your Fstop at about F8 or so.
Take your ISO as low as it will go.
Again, have your speed where it needs to be to hand held and still get a picture.
steps.description: It will probably need to be at over 1/200 or so.

steps.headline: Holding your reflector (or having your VALS (Voice Activated Light Stand) hold it, reflect the light coming from the background back into your subject's face.
Sometimes, you will just have a darker location where the only light is from an open door.
steps.description: You might need to use multiple reflectors.

steps.headline: Use your school geometry to figure out the angles that you need to get a photo.
steps.description: There have been photographers that have used 4 or more reflectors for an image.

steps.headline: Take the smaller reflector (if you are using various sizes) and direct the final light to where you need it on your subject's face.
Open your lens as wide as you can to get the shot you want.
Unless you want a grainy look, set the aperture as low as you can.
Unless you are using a tripod (which wouldn't be a bad idea), be sure that the speed is going to get you an image.

methods.name: Photographing at the Market  in Bright Sunlight

steps.headline: Set your aperture depending on whether or not you want the background to show.
steps.description: A wide aperture will probably allow too much light, so you are better off with a narrower aperture.

steps.headline: Take your reflector and, while holding it, move it around so that the light is reflected back on the subject's face.

text: Steps Get your reflectors. The best kind to get are the ones that will fold up very small with multiple colors of reflectors. There are several brands. Get what works best for you. You can bring larger ones that fold up in the same way for more elaborate shots, but you won't be carrying all of that gear while being a tourist! Keep it with you in your camera bag at all times.  Use It as a Light Source If you are in a darkened room or house and don't want to use your flash, position your subject appropriately. You want him facing a direction that you will be able to utilize existing light. Position the reflector under the chin, about chest height or so, and make sure the reflector is reflecting any available light.  Open your lens as far as it will go. You want as much light to get in as possible. Make sure that your shutter speed is set high enough that you won't have to worry about camera shake, unless you are using a tripod. You will probably have to experiment with the different speeds. Too fast, the scene will be dark, too slow, your subject will move or blink, or any of a hundred different things. Set your ISO as low as you can get it. You probably don't want grain, so you don't want it high. Start out at about 200 and go from there. Filling a Face and Preserving a Background Put your subject where you need them to be.  Expose for the background. If you try to expose for the subject, then the background will be very blown out. Have your Fstop at about F8 or so. Experiment with that. Take your ISO as low as it will go.  Again, have your speed where it needs to be to hand held and still get a picture. It will probably need to be at over 1/200 or so. Holding your reflector (or having your VALS (Voice Activated Light Stand) hold it, reflect the light coming from the background back into your subject's face.  Daisy Chain Your Reflectors Sometimes, you will just have a darker location where the only light is from an open door. You might need to use multiple reflectors. Use your school geometry to figure out the angles that you need to get a photo. There have been photographers that have used 4 or more reflectors for an image. Take the smaller reflector (if you are using various sizes) and direct the final light to where you need it on your subject's face.  Open your lens as wide as you can to get the shot you want.  Unless you want a grainy look, set the aperture as low as you can. 100 - 400 are good places to start. Unless you are using a tripod (which wouldn't be a bad idea), be sure that the speed is going to get you an image.  Photographing at the Market  in Bright Sunlight Set your aperture depending on whether or not you want the background to show. A wide aperture will probably allow too much light, so you are better off with a narrower aperture. Take your reflector and, while holding it, move it around so that the light is reflected back on the subject's face.
